Join the Nation's Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Lowe's job cuts hit home at N.C. headquarters USA TODAY 7:28 p.m. ET Feb. 21, 2017 Wes Bielinski, in red vest, helps a customer shop for a sander at a Lowe's home improvement store in Chicago (Photo: Scott Olson, Getty Images) CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Lowe's is cutting 525 staff at its headquarters and other facilities as part of a continued reshuffle of its organization, the home improvement chain confirmed Tuesday. 
Lowe's said that in Mooresville, N.C., where it is based, it has reduced about 430 corporate office positions, about 70 support positions in Wilkesboro and about 25 corporate support positions in other facilities. 
The changes are in keeping with a recently announced plan to reduce support positions while focusing more on jobs that help customers in stores. In all, 2,400 jobs are expected to be cut. 
"Lowe’s is engaged in a comprehensive effort to refocus and prioritize resources to ensure we have the right organizational structure in place to support our omnichannel strategy and customers’ expectations," the company said in a statement. 
The goal, it said, is to be "focused on creating a more agile and efficient operating structure for corporate-based positions that will enable us to be more responsive to customers’ evolving needs." 
The new staffing model was said to result in the reduction of one to two assistant store managers per store. 
Additionally, some leadership roles in the Customer Support and Distribution Centers were to be consolidated, impacting 37 employees nationwide and about 10% of vice presidents in the corporate office. 
In total, the reduction impacts less than 1% of the Lowe's workforce, or roughly 2,400 employees. 
Marketing experts believe Lowe's is trying to better compete with rival Home Depot. 
"It is always difficult to make decisions like these that affect our people, but sometimes they are necessary as we build for the future and meet the evolving needs of consumers," said Karen Cobb, manager of corporate public relations. 
Cobb said that the company would be providing the affected employees with a transition package including severance pay, outplacement resources and other support.
